title-group.article-title: Patients’ Perceptions of Cosmetic Surgery at a Time of Globalization, Medical Consumerism, and Mass Media Culture
title-group.subtitle: A French Experience

contrib-group.aff: Dr Lazar is a Senior Surgeon in the Department of Plastic Surgery, Meulan Regional Hospital, Meulan, France
Dr Deneuve is a Senior Surgeon in the Department of Head and Neck Surgery, Gustave Roussy Institute, Villejuif, France

author-notes.corresp: Dr Câlin Constantin Lazar, Senior Surgeon, Department of Plastic Surgery, Meulan Regional Hospital, 1 Rue du Fort, 78250 Meulan, France. E-mail: lazarcalin@yahoo.fr

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: The global popularity of cosmetic surgery, combined with mass media attention on medical consumerism, has resulted in misinformation that may have negatively affected the “collective image” of aesthetic practitioners.

sec.title: Objectives:
sec.p: The authors assess patients’ perceptions of cosmetic surgery and analyze their decision-making processes.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: During a 2-year period, 250 consecutive patients presenting to either of 2 public hospitals for cosmetic surgery treatment were asked to complete a 7-item questionnaire evaluating their knowledge of opinions about, and referring practices for, aesthetic procedures. Patients undergoing oncologic, postbariatric, or reconstructive procedures were not included in the study.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: After exclusion of 71 cases for refusal or incompletion, 179 questionnaires were retained and analyzed (from 162 women and 17 men). Overall, repair (70.4%), comfort (45.3%), and health (40.8%) were the words most frequently associated with cosmetic surgery. Quality of preoperative information (69.3%), patient-physician relationship (65.4%), and results seen in relatives/friends (46.3%) were the most important criteria for selecting a cosmetic surgeon. Moreover, 82.7% of patients knew the difference between cosmetic surgery and cosmetic medicine.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: Although potential patients appear to be more educated about cosmetic surgery than they were several years ago, misinformation still persists. As physicians, we must be responsible for disseminating accurate education and strengthening our collaboration with general practitioners to improve not only our results but also the accuracy of information in the mass media.

body.p: Television programs that are broadcast worldwide tend to reduce cosmetic surgery to easy “show business” procedures. Examples of such shows include Prête à Tout Pour Plaire in Belgium, Make Me Perfect in the United Kingdom, and The Swan and Extreme Makeover in the United States. Although these popular “reality shows” have contributed to normalizing our subspecialty, they also have potential adverse effects on their audiences.1-4 Most of these shows are silent about the real scope of the speciality5 as well as the possible risks and complications, while persuading patients that anyone can undergo such “simple” surgery.3,4,6-8 Because they showcase rapid results and exaggerated positive outcomes, these programs mislead the audience into believing that all aesthetic procedures have the same level of safety and ease, which plays a significant role in patient decision making.3,9-13 On the opposite end of the spectrum, some expensive and/or failed operations covered by the media give the notion of a specialty populated by unscrupulous and inexperienced surgeons.

Today, the web has become one of the most important sources of information for consumers considering cosmetic surgery.14 In addition to being important tools in marketing and public relations, our websites allow us to provide clear and honest information to patients.15 However, the web also can act as a showcase for unethical behaviors. The most popular and easy-to-find commercial plastic surgery websites are often incomplete, lacking essential information about complications and difficulty of follow-up.3,16-19 Potential patients can be directed to too many web pages boasting solely about a surgeon’s skills8 or offering surgical trips or bargains, implying in a way that choosing a surgeon would be comparable to buying a car.3

Overexposure and inaccurate information concerning cosmetic surgery are problems that should not be ignored by physicians or by national health systems. In this era of constant increases in cosmetic procedures and surgical lawsuits,4,11,20 the relationship between cosmetic surgery and the media can be a dangerous one3,8,10 that may threaten our practices. However, very few studies in the international literature have examined people’s perceptions of cosmetic procedures and surgeons. Therefore, in an effort to provide information that will help us combat potential misunderstandings, we report the results of a prospective 2-year study analyzing the opinions of 179 French patients considering cosmetic surgery for the first time.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This study was conducted in 2 French public hospitals between January 2008 and December 2009. Data were obtained through an anonymous questionnaire specifically created for this analysis by the authors. This questionnaire, originally written in French, included 7 items (Table 1). These paper-based surveys were administered by a nurse to 250 patients at the time of their initial consultation. All recipients of the questionnaire were able to read and write in French. Patients who had been referred for oncologic or reconstructive surgery (including interventions after massive weight loss) were systematically excluded from the study and did not receive the survey.

tr.td: (1) Which referral method brought you to our facility for a CS consultation?
(2) Are cosmetic medicine and CS the same speciality?
(4) Compared with other surgical specialties, rank the risks in CS.
(5) Which 2 of these 10 words do you associate most with CS?
(6) Which 3 of these 10 factors are the most influential in choosing your cosmetic surgeon?

Immediate surgeryQuality of preoperative informationSurgeon’s feesSurgeon’s scientific worksOffice/clinic appearancePatient-physician relationshipSurgeon’s media-related reputationResults seen in family and friendsSurgeon’s years of practicePostoperative photographs on website
(7) What do you think about “surgical tourism”?
Not interestedYou need informationSeems coolYou’d like to have the choiceYou’ll certainly do it

sec.p: While waiting for their consultation, patients completed their surveys. The questionnaires were collected by the same nurse who had administered them, before the consultation began. Seventy-one questionnaires were excluded (36 for incomplete answers and 35 for patient refusal), and the remaining 179 were analyzed at the end of the study period.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Results are presented in Table 2. Of the 179 respondents whose questionnaires were included among the final results, 162 were women and 17 were men. (The disparate gender ratio precluded any significant comparison of answers between men and women in this study.) The study population included 136 people in the workforce, 19 students, 14 homemakers, and 10 retired persons. The mean age of the study patients was 37 years (range, 23-68 years). Education level was not analyzed.

tr.td: Results seen in family and friends
You’d like to have the choice

fn.p: Data for Questions 1 and 7 total more than 179 because multiple choices could be selected.

sec.p: Within the decision-making process for cosmetic surgery consultation, the role of the general practitioner (GP) was similar in importance to that of patients’ families/friends and the media: 40.8%, 38.5%, and 33.0% of patients (respectively) noted that these were the primary methods of referral. Most patients (82.7%) knew that there is a difference between cosmetic surgery as a specialty and cosmetic medicine. For 96.1% of study patients, cosmetic surgery was considered a “real” medical specialty requiring a specific qualification. Most patients (85.5%) understood that cosmetic surgery exposes patients to the same risks as other surgeries.

Of the options provided, the words most often associated with cosmetic surgery were repair (70.4%), comfort (45.3%), and health (40.8%). We were surprised by the low rate of pejorative words associated with the specialty, considering the heavy media influence. Patients reported that, of the choices given, the 3 most important criteria for choosing a surgeon were quality of preoperative information (69.3%), patient-physician relationship (65.4%), and results seen in family and friends (46.3%). Concerning medical tourism, although 23.5% of our patients lacked information on the subject, 93.3% admitted to not being interested in it.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Our study was limited by several factors, including the relatively small number of patients, the conceivable specificity of the French population, and the use of an invalidated questionnaire. On the basis of results of other studies,21 we believe that the invalidated nature of our survey was justified by the absence (to our knowledge) of any specific survey addressing the subject of our work. Despite the limitations of our study, we believe that our data can yield several benefits for the aesthetic surgery community.

sec.title: General Practitioners as a Referral Source
sec.p: First, with regard to question 1 (method of referral), general practitioners play a central role in the French health care system and, since 2005, have been recognized as specialists. All French patients must declare a referring GP, and only those patients sent to a specialist by their GP can expect significant reimbursement of their medical expenses. In our study, the GP appeared to play an important referral role in our patients’ final decisions to pursue cosmetic surgery—slightly higher than that played by family and the media. In other countries, the media role is more significant, most likely attributable to current omnipresent information.22 However, in France, personal advertising through the media is prohibited.23 Professional websites are supposed to exist for informational purposes only. Moreover, not all French surgeons have their own website. This may explain why our findings may differ from other published data.21

In our opinion, a strong working partnership with the GP appears essential, especially for cosmetic surgeons in France. Besides being the patient’s “gatekeeper” to access secondary health care services,24-30 the GP can help us fight today’s modified perception of cosmetic surgery due to certain media messages (for which we are partially responsible).3,8,31 Together, we can improve information on cosmetic surgery and raise awareness of the dangers of “show business” medicine.

sec.title: Cosmetic Surgery vs Cosmetic Medicine
sec.p: With regard to the differences between cosmetic surgery as a specialty and cosmetic medicine (questions 2 and 3 of the survey), it should be noted that, until the recent past and within the wide scope of the medical diploma, any French physician was allowed to perform any surgical procedure within his or her field of knowledge. Some general physicians were performing cosmetic surgery procedures more or less successfully but discrediting the specialty to a certain degree. The situation has changed as a result of the creation of the National Diploma of Plastic, Reconstructive, and Aesthetic Surgery (1988) and the limiting of cosmetic surgery procedures only to authorized institutions (2002) working with qualified and registered specialist cosmetic surgeons (2005). Due to these efforts, France has been recognized on an international level for its cosmetic surgery safety standards.23 However, France still remains far behind the world’s top 5 nations regarding the quantity of procedures performed and the number of board-certified surgeons.32,33 In 2011, there were only 727 plastic surgeons in France34 as opposed to 5970 in the United States, which ranked first. (The approximate ratio of surgeons to inhabitants was 1:89 260 in France, 1:52 430 in the United States, 1:40 490 in Brazil, and 1:669 850 in China.33)

Patients who participated in our study seem to understand the uniqueness of our specialty (n = 172), as well as its difference from cosmetic medicine (n = 148). However, confusion still persists in the media, which often associates the term cosmetic surgery with nonsurgical aesthetic techniques. Similar results have already been reported in the specialized literature.35 However, like other investigators, we believe that the growth in requests for nonsurgical cosmetic procedures may represent an important change in the future of our practice.20,35 As the number of nonsurgical cosmetic procedures performed worldwide continues to increase,32,33 it would be wise for plastic surgeons to play a more active role in this new, interesting, and competitive market.

sec.title: Words Associated With Cosmetic Surgery
sec.p: Despite recent issues (eg, PIP implants, interdiction of several lipolysis techniques36), a certain laxity concerning illegal practitioners, and reality shows that emphasize the “show business” or malpractice aspects of cosmetic surgery, the words malpractice (0%), lawsuit (0.5%), and failure (1.7%) were rarely associated with cosmetic surgery by the patients in our study. This may relate to the strict requirements23 for all French board-certified plastic surgeons, such as providing patients with systematic, comprehensive preoperative information on the procedure, including a detailed explanation of potential risks and complications, as well as a detailed financial quote; a mandatory waiting period of at least 15 days; rigorous quality standards for facilities at which cosmetic surgery is performed; national commissions for supervision and control; and prohibition of publicity/advertising and facilities that combine commercial accommodation and surgical suites.

sec.title: Legal Matters
sec.p: This may also explain why medicosurgical lawsuits37-41 remain rare in France42,43; however, the number of complaints is increasing.42 Approximately 4070 cases with indemnities exceeding 15 000 euros were registered by the French monitoring center of medical risks from 2006 to 2009, only 68 of which were referred to plastic and aesthetic surgery, with an average indemnity of 59 500 euros.42 However, as 14.5% of French patients still underrate the risks of cosmetic surgery and may have unrealistic expectations and evaluation of surgical results,44,45 it is our responsibility to supplement their lack of information.10,46 Overall, to avoid unnecessary dissatisfaction and adverse events, candidates should be carefully selected only after thorough analysis of their motives and expectations. Potential patients also should be provided with high-quality preoperative consultations, and surgical procedures should always comply with documented guidelines.3,31,44,47-53

sec.title: Factors Influencing Patient Preferences
sec.p: As noted earlier, the main factors influencing the patient’s choice of surgeon were quality of preoperative information, patient-physician relationship, and results seen in family and friends.22,53 Also important, but to a lesser degree, were surgeon’s fees, surgeon’s number of years in practice, office/clinic appearance,30 surgeon’s media-related reputation, surgeon’s scientific works, and postoperative photographs, some of which are displayed on physicians’ websites.19 The lesser impact of a practitioner’s scientific works or number of years in practice on the patients’ choices30 could be explained by patients’ lack of knowledge in these areas. The relative importance of factors such as money, surgeon’s fees, and the option to undergo immediate surgery should not be overlooked. These considerations emphasize the phenomenon of medical consumerism,54-59 including the notion of medical tourism.

sec.title: Private vs Public Health System
sec.p: Our results might be limited by the public nature of our practice. Substantial differences exist between the private and public systems. In France, cosmetic surgery is funded by the patient, and the surgical fee is collected directly from the patient on the day of service. However, depending on whether the practice is private or public, there are major differences in the medical fees assessed for identical surgeries.

In the French public health system, the surgeon is paid by the hospital,60 at a much lower rate than in the United States.61 Accordingly, cosmetic surgery patients pay only an “administrative daily rate,” which usually is reevaluated annually by the Health Department. In May 2013, the cost of a 24-hour hospitalization, including anesthesia and surgery, was around 1550 euros regardless of the surgical procedure.

On the other hand, a private surgeon manages his or her own business and is free to set specific fees, including additional fees for surgical facility, anesthesia, and other miscellaneous costs related to surgery. Therefore, private surgeons may charge their patients much more than public surgeons (Table 3). In any case, these fees are still much lower than in the United States,62 and the private practitioner’s average income is significantly lower in France than in the United States and many other countries.63-65 Although a French patient is free to choose between the 2 systems, the problem of unfair competition is not an issue in France because plastic surgery departments are rare in public practice. They exist mostly in university hospitals, and surgeons in those institutions mainly perform reconstructive surgery and general plastic surgery procedures with few cosmetic surgery procedures and almost no cosmetic medicine. Moreover, in public practice, patients may experience long delays awaiting the availability of a senior surgeon or have a supervised resident perform the surgery. Therefore, depending on patients’ financial means, how long they are willing to wait, whether they wish to select a specific surgeon, and whether nonsurgical cosmetic intervention is desired, private practice may be the more attractive alternative (perhaps even extending into surgical tourism). It should be noted that private and tourism sectors have a greater web presence than public practices.

caption.p: Approximate Overall Costs of Common Plastic Surgery Procedures: Public vs Private Practice

sec.title: Surgical Tourism
sec.p: Considered to be a worldwide “problem,”18,19,66-68 surgical tourism in France mainly involves cosmetic surgery and dental care. The main destinations for residents of France are Eastern Europe and North Africa,16,35,69 whereas popular destinations for US citizens are India, Costa Rica, and Thailand.70 Unfortunately, despite increasingly aggressive advertising campaigns in the media and on the web financed by foreign companies able to advertise in France because French law does not apply to them,23 official French organizations (eg, General Medical Council, National Health Department) remain relatively silent about this phenomenon. Moreover, surgical tourism falls outside regulations that are mandatory for all French plastic surgeons.23 This situation exposes the French population to many well-known risks related to surgical tourism, such as insufficient medical qualifications of practitioners, significant difficulties due to long-distance follow-up, and problems related to insurance; it also raises new juridical risks for domestic practitioners.18,66,71 As with citizens of the United States,70 it is hoped that the number of French residents traveling overseas for surgical interventions will remain low.

The patients in our study did not respond positively to surgical tourism, perhaps because they have had the opportunity to undergo surgery in the public system and pay lower tariffs than proposed abroad. Nevertheless, in times of economic hardship, a patient’s medical choice may become more heavily influenced by financial considerations or associated “benefits” (eg, sunny climate, seaside location, luxurious resort).66,72 Accordingly, we must prevent cosmetic surgery from being the subject of this type of marketing campaign.19,31,68,73,74 In our opinion, surgical tourism may be an acceptable alternative for cases of certain pathologies that are not typically managed in domestic health care systems or where cost is a concern for patients seeking common, uncomplicated procedures. However, surgical tourism will continue to be associated with risks and serious ethical problems.75-77 Certain procedures are not approved in some countries (eg, liquid silicone injections) yet are available in others, domestic patients’ needs may be neglected in the destination country, and there may be uncertainty about safety procedures and a lack of skilled practitioners and proper coordination by respectable health care providers.70,76,78 All of these issues warrant further investigation and effective solutions.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Compared with the United States, which ranks first in the field of cosmetic surgery, the French system differs vastly in terms of advertising, legal restrictions, number of certified surgeons, procedures performed, average surgical income, and quantity of malpractice cases. Since strict standards for cosmetic surgery practice were adopted in France, French patients seem to focus more on word of mouth, safety factors, and quality of information in making surgical decisions than on marketing, media advertising, or surgical tourism. Although patients worldwide appear to be better educated about cosmetic surgery than they were several years ago, misinformation persists. As physicians, we must be responsible for disseminating accurate information and strengthening collaborations with general practitioners. We must guarantee our patients optimum education and management, deal cautiously with broadcast information and images related to cosmetic surgery and medicine, and discourage patients from traveling to foreign countries to undergo “discount” procedures. Because of the limits of our study, the results should be interpreted with caution. Further investigation is warranted.

ack.p: The authors are grateful to Nikki Sabourin-Gibbs, Rouen University Hospital, for reviewing the English version of the manuscript.

fn.label: Disclosures
fn.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The authors received no financial support for the research, authorship, and publication of this article.
